newsitem.title: USA: Dole airs controversial new ad pushing tax cuts.
newsitem.headline: Dole airs controversial new ad pushing tax cuts.

text.p: Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole's campaign on Wednesday unveiled a new television ad pushing his tax-cut plan, saying Americans "shouldn't have to apologize" for wanting to keep their money.
The advertisement, which will be broadcast in 17 states, also takes aim at President Clinton's record, claiming he passed the biggest tax hike in history.

The spot opens with an announcer's voice criticizing the Clinton administration, saying: "Stagnant wages. The largest tax increase in history. Two incomes needed to make ends meet. Americans deserve better."
The announcer then turns to Dole's tax plan, built around a 15 percent across-the-board cut, saying: "Cut wasteful spending. Balance the budget. A tax cut of $1,600 for the typical family."
Dole himself appears, saying, "You shouldn't have to apologize for wanting to keep what you earn. It's your money."
The Republican candidate, who lags Clinton by double-digits in opinion polls, has used that line in a series of campaign appearances in the central and western parts of the country this week.
Clinton campaign spokesman Joe Lockhart replied by saying that Dole's commercial "shows how out of touch his campaign has become."

He said expert agreed that Dole's economic plan was wrong "because it will balloon the deficit, raise mortgage rates, and require even more extreme cuts in Medicare, Medicaid, education, and the environment than Newt Ginrich and Bob Dole fought for -- and President Clinton vetoed -- last year."

On Wednesday, Dole visited a day-care center in Des Moines, Iowa, and was presented with a three-year-old's drawing of the number 15 -- which he held up as proof that even children are thinking about his tax cut plan.
Dole flies later in the day to Wisconsin, Michigan and Ohio before returning to Washington Thursday.
